This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

THURSDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1906

THE SOLDIER'S FUTURE. "A great social problem" is Mr. Haldane's description of the difficulty of equipping the soldier for a civilian occupation after he leaves the colours, and of finding employment for the many thousands of men who annually enter the Reserves and are thrown upon the labour market.

It is a three-fold problem. It affects, in the first instance, the class and type of man who enlists in the land forces of the Crown. With all the endeavours of Army reformers to make the pay and conditions of service more attractive to the healthy and adventurous youth of the country, but little has been done officially in practical form to ensure a reason. able future to the man when he is no longer fed, clothed, and quartered by the State and has to make a fresh start with his liability as Reservist upon his shoulders. The result is an initial and constant difficulty in recruiting, excepting in times of acute industrial distress, and an unwillingness on the part of the most desirable kind of lad to join the colours, although in the last few years the general standard of the recruits has admittedly improved. Secondly, the problem involves the directing of the soldier's attention to his own interests, a proposition which may appear unmeaning, but which is a very real stumblingblock in the way, of all who are most diligently active for the men's welfare. Under present conditions a man enlists for a variety of reasons, but seldom enough with an eye to the future. He is in trouble in his village and "goes for a soldier"; or he does not like the employment to which he has been put; or trade is bad and he sees no chance of getting work. Of course, there are numerous exceptions to this generalization soldier families among the rank and file who in turn follow the colours as naturally and proudly as the oldest of our Naval or AngloIndian septs. But the average recruit, good man as he often turns out to be, has joined the Army he hardly knows why or how and with no very definite object in view. To open up a field of subsequent civilian employment for him demands of him a certain sacrifice of leisure, industry, and money in order that he may, while still serving, gain knowledge at work-shops and classes of technical instruction. Proverbially improvident and shortsighted, he forgets during the years of physical comfort while he is in the service the stress of life that awaits him on leaving the Army and he is not, with few exceptions, inclined to add to his routine military duties the self-imposed task of learning the rudiments of a civilian calling. In its third aspect the problem concerns the employers of labour.

The old, deep-seated prejudice against the soldier is dying out, but it dies hard. Many great employment concerns in the country systematically do their utmost to find places for the ex-Regular. Government Departments are in certain cases, notably that of the Post Office, under a definite agreement with the War Office as to the number of billets annually to be allotted to him; some of the railway companies make a point of taking on as many Reservists, as possible; a group of the greatest manufacturing firms of the country have numbers of old soldiers on their wages sheets..

These, however, are only the few broad avenues of regular employment into which a comparatively few fortunate and specially. fitted men are able to pass; the great bulk of the many thousands per annuin remain Mr. Haldane's great social problem. How to give the man during his period of service an adequate amount of civilian training, and, having done that, how to bring him into ready touch with the employer in need of his labour, formed the subject of an exhaustive inquiry carried out by a Special Committee under Sir Edward Ward in the earlier part of the year, whose recommendations have recently been published. ("Tribune”)

utforines in London, and was only stopped Becanje. the majority of the members of the Haylineham Clab where's gain it. HouseBoat for Sudan Biologist. ..

The vessel was towed to Sued by one of the Company's togs and tbare handed over to the Khedivial Mail Steamship Company who have undertaken to tow her down the Red Sea to Port Sadan.' THE MINISTRIES.
We understand that nothing has been definitely decided as to the future situation of the Ministries of Justice, Foreign Affairs, the

Interior, Publio Construction, and Finance. The 1 -Government bas considered the possibility of erecting new buildings on new sites, and Mukhtar Pasha's Palace and the Kasr el Nil Barracks with the adjoining parade ground have been suggested as suitable spots. But the Ottoman High Commissioner shows no anxiety, to leave bis palace and nothing whatever has been decided as to the future of l of tbe Kasr el Nil Barrack

Lo fact as far as the five Ministries above li mentioned are concerned everything is in the air. The principle that three new buildings, one for the Ministry of Public Instruction, one for Justice and Foreign Affairs, and one for the Interior and Finance shall be erected hasil been admitted, the more readily sinoe the present buildings are by no means substantial, and require constant and considerable l. repair. Bat as to their new cite or the date of their commencement nothing has been selected 1 and nothing is known. They may be commenced within five years or in fifteen and none of i the sites favoured by common gossip may 1 have the honour of being selected.

On the other hand the drawings for a new li War Office have been completed the specifications are being prepared, and be foundation pita sunk. The new Diwan 2 Harbiya will be built almost at right angles to the present, Ministries of War and Public Works on the li line between the chemical laboratory and the Sudan Office. The latter building will be demolished and when the new War Office, in which the Sudan Office will be invaded, is completed, the Ministry of Public Works will occupy the present quarters of the War Office officials.

THE KHEDIVE. His Highness is spending to-day st Montazah. He drove through Alexandria yesterday in company with Mantapba Pasha Ibadi, Governor of Alexandria. His Highness left Ras-elTin Palace at 4.30 p.m., and proceeded to Bidi Gaber station for Montazh.
The Khedive will come to Alexandria to morrow to attend prayer.
The Khediyah on landing yesterday morning I proceeded direct to Monte xeh with the Khe divial family
. H. the Khedive received yesterday in audience Prince Mohamed Aly, and Captain Blaker ey.
The Mabronses on the voyage from Cou stantinople to Alexandria was under the command of Hasran Ibady Bey, A.D.C. to his Highness.

CHERIF PASHA ESTATE. In the Mixed Court of Probate, before Judge Vasquez y amor, osme op for hearing yesterday morning the suit brought by the widow' (nee Colombani) of the late Mohamed Pasha't Cherit, ex Under Secretary of State for ForeignAffairs, who died in Paris, in August, praying 1 for the appointment of a judicial executor of the estate of the deceased, of which she was entitled to one-third, by an eilam sharieh of the Court. The defendant is Ibrahim Bey Cherif, who as son of the opole of the deceased Pasha, claims right of inheritance, a claim which is contested in the present litigation.

The defendant opposes the legality of the appointment by the Mixed Tribunal of such an executor, and on the plea of its incompetence, demanded that such appointment be made by the Native Court, on the ground that all the heirs were Ottoman subjects, and that the Crédit Foncier, with which the estate was hypothecated, had no actual interest. Defendant also opposed the appointment of Moharrem Pasha Ibrahim, and pot forward other dominees. | The case of the plaintiff is supported by all the other relatives of the deceased, viz., the mother of the deceased, who is widow of the celebrated Charif Pasha. Frangori, one time Premier and Regent, his sisters Dames Mobarrem Pasha Shahin and Abdelrabim Bey Sabri, as also the Crédit Poncier Egyptien.

Por the plaintiff Maitre Carton de Wiart contested the Ottoman nationality of his 1 client, which was not established in jurisprudence, citing article 19. of the Civil Code and the Law of 1863 ; and that the Mixed Tribunal was alone competent to grant probate, in view of the fact that the estate was hypothecated with the Crédit Foncier. Moltres Goarjon and Nassif represent the heirs, Maire Wissa Was
sif, Ibrahim Bey, defendant, M.Itre Chalom and y the Crédit Foncier.

MUSTAPHA PASHA KAMEL.

A few days ago the Havas Agency telegraph ed from Paris that Mustapha Pasba Kamel had written to Farid Bey suggesting the formation of a National University, which would unite all Egyptians and strengthen the national sentiment. The following is the letter:

"My dear Farid Bey, "I have just heard through "Al Lowa" that & committee has been formed at Cairo for the purpose of opening a public subscription in order to offer me a banquet as a testimony of the satisfaction felt by Egyptians for the services I have rendered to my beloved country. I learn, on the other hand, that you have undertaken to act as treasurer for this committee. Allow me to ask you to communicate to the members of the committee and to those who have been good enough to accept their invitation my warmest thanks for the sym. pathie kindness they have shown towards a man who thinks that what he has done is a mere drop in the ocean of duty incumbent on every Egyptian. For my part I never in my ļife believed that I was worthy of such a mark of esteem or of gratitude for my champion ing of the rights of Egypt, for the struggle I have waged for its freedom and for my appeals to the patriotism of the Egyptiane. I have simply fulfilled a snored daty, and it is only to day that I have made the first steps towards conducting our beloved country towards the goal of prosperity. What then is the need of my merit, since the humblest soldier in an army displays to the whole world the noblest lesson and the noblest example Is it pot he who carries the standard of his country! Is it not he who defends its honour, its prestige and its independence, and who is the first to lay down his life in order to save the lives of millions of old men, women, and children 1

If such be the position of each member of an army how many ard how great are the duties, which we owe to our native land. We have enjoyed its benefits,--we who have received an intellectual education, and who are | conscious of all our obligations and who have bebeld the light of truth twinks before our) eyes; who have contemplated the greatness of civilised nations and who are perforce obliged! to acknowledge their greatness and our inferiority. I am infinitely obliged to you, but I cannot bring myself to accept mark of esteem and favour which I do not deserve, and I refuse to allow that a man can be rewarded for his patriotism, as if devoid of that noble feeling he cannot be called a man. I am well aware that you desire to invoke the splendid ides of our native land through my poor personality, and that you wish to raise her i standard in your hands, for it is only this idea

and this sentiment which in reality 'my foes and my adversaries are fighting. But be not afraid | The object of your hopes is attained, for the banner of Egyptian patriotism floats majestically despite every calumny and every assault. The whole world has now learnt that the sap of life flows in our veins, and that we are eager to obtain glory in advancing along the right path. The whole world is convinced that We seek life and want a legitimate and legal constitution and freedom. The entire world has been convinced that what we want is the happiness of our country by means of education, labor, and reason. Buch a result was never anticipated by the enemies of Egypt and the Egyptians after that it had been generally believed that the question of Egyptian independence bad beep buried, and that quietened Boglish diplomacy.

And it is thus that I suggest to you the ides of a far greater gift that we can offer to our dear country. May the appeals of your committee sound throughout Egypt, and go straight to the heart of all Egyptians, We desire to fogod a National University which will shelter the children of the rich and the poor. This University will give us men strong and sincere, men fearless of menace, and who will brave chastisement; physicians and apostles who will hell and teach in turn, Sgoh is the anique gift worthy to be offered to Egypt by ber true patriots ; such the great present that will fill the soul with life, and sound the transports of felicity; such the imperious demonstration of life and sentiment, May factiong forget their strife, and the Prese unite; may animosity disappear, at least for a day, and may the harmony of anion be heard in all its splendour; may the nation consolidate - for bigger interests are at stake ! May all remember. ber that amongst these children of the poor whom the Occupation has covered from light and learning, there are great minds.
Encircled by the acreole of science, they might have been the glory of Egypt. May those who love and feel remember that in our midst there are treasures hidden ; there tres
ures will flood the earth with their splendor; they shine, but they are buried in the soil of

be poor. What would be my happiness and my joy if one day I might lay one stone in the crest edifice of our University, in company with the e august workers who labour only for good, and who desire neither reward nor favour .

THE KAMEL BANQUET. Most decidedly our Nationalists do not all love the Kameloorsey. "Al Minbar" publishes a letter, signed "Said Bosa," the author of which, so far from announcing his intention of appearing at the banquet in honour of the patriot, states that he would prefer to see Mustapha's rich friends devoting their cash to adacational objects instead of wasting money on a copious bar qnet which will have no effect whatever. Evidently the feast will be sump taons, and we may expect the communicative beat with which M. Pelletan has made 08 Familiar to kindle the permanence of the banqueters into a perfect consortium of indiscretions.

THE LATE MAJOR JOHNSTONE.
MEMORIAL SERVICE.

A memorial service was held at 6 o'clock yesterday afternoon at All Saints' Church, Cairo, in memory of the late Major L'Estrange Johnstone, RE. Many friends and colleagues of the deceased officer were present, and nome ous wreaths had been gent and were arranged in the chancel of the oburoh. Amongst those present we may mention Lord Bdward Cecil, Mr. Parnell, Mr. Alban, Captain Blakeney, Mr. Verschoyle, and the greater portion of the European staff of the State Railways, li Skander Pashs Fehmy, most of the officers of the Royal Engineers who are at progent in Egypt, British, Turkish, and Keyptian officers of the Khedive's army, etc. The service was fully choral, and conducted by the Rev. Thomas Barns, and at the close of the congrega: tion rose for the rendering of the 'Dead March in Saal."

NEW VICTORIA HOTEL. In view of the increasing popularity of this fashionable hotel, the energotio proprietor has decided to add a large wing to the present building to provide for upwards of sixty rooms. By this arrangement the main entrance will face doe South, a decided advantage; this will lead into magnificent vestibule to connect with the present dining hall, and it is contemplated to run a terrace over the strip of garden now in front of the hotel, the part now occupied by the main entrance being converted into a band stand. The work on the anoex, which is to begin in a fortnight, will in no wise interfere with the comfort or arrangements of the hotel which will remain open all winter, for which season special terms will be made. A motor car is shortly expected for the benefit of the hotel traffic. Both from its healthy position and its aristocratic surroundings, the new hotel is to be highly commended to tourists and residents.
A CASE FOR ENQUIRY.

"L, Journal du Caire" makes a statement which, it truro, demands the attention of the authorities. Oar confrère declares that three young Baropean girls were followed in the Mouski on Tuesday afternoon by a group of natives who made obeaune observations to them and even dared to lay hands on them. The police, it adds, turned their backs and remarked "No matter they are only Beropean women!" Should this statement be confirmed we trust severe example will be made of these extraordinary sba wishes. This is not the first time that an incident of this sort has been reported.
TANTAH AGRICULTURAL SHOW.

Two days ago, Hassan Pasba Radwan, Mudir of Gharbieh, left 'Tantab for Cairo in order to make farther preparations for the Tantah Agricultural Show, which will be held shortly on the 11th, 12th, and 13th inst.
K.R.RS. FOR ALEXANDRIA.

The detachment of the 1st Battalion King's Royal Rifle Corps, approximating a strength of four officers and 290 non commissioned officers and mon, which is to be stationed at Alexandria, will entrain at Cairo, Abbassieh siding, to-morrow. They will be quartered at Ras el Tin barracks. .

THE MONEY FAMINE.

Alexandria has been addenly denuded of gold within the last few days, and considerable inconvenience has resulted from this scarcity of the precious metal. The banks are consjug for the time being to advance money and great are the complaints therefore, as it is the firm on viction of everybody here, who has banking account, that they can overdraw to an unlimited extent. This present acute state of penury is due to the fact that cotton has gone to a very high price at the beginning of the season. It is true that such prices havo been seen before, but never at the opening of the season, and the result is that an enormous financial drain bas ensued. Growers find the present prices so very remunerative that they Are selling their cotton wholesale. The merchants naturally have to boy when the natives want to sell and the vendors insist on cash on delivery of their stocks in their own villages are at the ginning centres. Such a roh for money has never before been known at the Alexandrian banks as has taken place within the last tew days and as Alexandria is the cotton financing centre of Egypt, the stringency has been particularly acate bere, bat almost as severe a crisis is also being experienced in Cairo. The banks had amplo cash reserves for a normal demand up to a week ago, but pince Monday, week over £2,000,000 have been withdrawn here and sent to the interior in bard cash. Within the last three days the National Bank of Egypt at Alexandria has paid out £510,000, and the same sort of thing is the tale at every bank.
Half a million sterling is arriving at Alex andria on Monday next by the Austrian Lloyd steamer. This, however, is probably all earmarked already, so it will in no way relieve the situation.
It was rumoured that half a million was on board the Isis, bat this is probably ontree, as all shipments of money from Bogland come by way of Trieste

A very satisfactory symptom of the healthy financial condition of the country deserves to be noted, and that is that at the present janctare the Boarse keeps very firm and despite the keepest need for gold, nobody finds himself so bard pat to it as to realise to any serious extent.

Some are inclined to find fault with the banks, for it is argued that it had been known for some time before that the season was going to open at high prices and that natives would avail themselves of the occasion to sell, but although the banks made some provision 2 it has proved quite insufficient and that a little foresight should have enabled them to lay in much bigger stocks of money. But in justice to the banks it must be remembered that there have been times when owing to the willingness of growers to realise their orops the banks have found themselves running op *, heavy bill for interest to no purpose. Others lay the blame on the Government, but we really fail to see that the Government have got anything to do with the case.

There is, however, one direction in which the Government might take steps to do something to mitigate any feature stringency. Very large payments are due on account of the land tax in October, November, and December. These months are chosen as at this time of the year the follab has plenty of money. It might be possible to enforce a less cumbersome form of machinery for getting this money back into circulation again. The Moodirieh authorities and the Caisse de la Dette koop this amount much too long a time out of circulation.

THE ISIS BREAKDOWN.
ARRANGEMENTS FOR MAILS.
Various are the ronsons assigned to the non-arrival of the P. and 0. mail-bont Isis, and we are unable to obtain any absoluto confirm
tion of any of the rumours afloat. That ber I engines broke down is certain, but whether

due to arch an explosion as is reported by Router's telegram of yesterday's data we cannot say. Most of our readers know the Isis as one of the two twin ships which do the weekly service from Port Said to Brindisi, and which carry the most important maile for and from England. She was built in 1899 and has
gross tonnage of 1,728 with horsepower of 6,500. The maximum speed attainable by the Isis and Osiris is said to be 91 koote, bot, we believe, they do not exceed 18 knots an hour Na rale.

It cannot be stated definitely when the maila will be received. We hear that the Persia, which arrived at Port Said on Tuesday, has gone to the Isis to take off her mails and passengers. The ustal Brindisi weekly outward mail will be carried next week by the Arcadia due from India on Sunday night, and that requal will afterwards go on to Maravillos.
